Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Developing High-Throughput CRISPR/Single-cell RNA-seq Screening in Maize
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project seeks to combine two powerful, new approaches to accelerate breeding of crops adapted to environmental stresses, providing new tools to deal with agricultural challenges such as minimizing loss from drought or heat. One of the technical approaches used in the project, known by its acronym CRISPR -- creates genetic variation much the same way it occurs randomly in nature but with much greater speed, ease and target precision. The second technique, known as single-cell RNA-sequencing, allows researchers to measure activity of, potentially, every gene in a single cell. Together, the two methods allow a "miniaturization" of the breeding approach -- testing many crop variants to find ones with useful agricultural traits. Different, single cell variants can be generated by the millions using CRISPR, subjected to a stress in which only the fittest cells survive, and those cells analyzed for the precise changes that allowed them to survive using single-cell RNA-sequencing. This method, used in conjunction with classical breeding approaches, can serve as a resource for plant breeders and geneticists working to understand the genetic regulators of traits that are important for stable crop production. In the education goals of the project, the investigators will extend a successful program that trains talented New York City high student interested in a career in science.

More specifically, this project aims to develop pooled CRISPR/single-cell RNA-seq screens in maize protoplasts to introduce a novel approach to plant breeding and genetic analysis. Using CRISPR and associated endonucleases like Cas9, large-scale genetic screens will be carried out in which a diverse set of guide-RNAs is transfected into a pool of millions of cells. The cells are then subjected to a selection; survivors identify beneficial perturbations while underrepresented genotypes in the pool identify genes necessary to survive the stress. Coupled with single-cell RNA-seq, this approach provides a sensitive readout of genetic pathways, and has been used successfully in animal cells. The method has not yet been applied to plants and could not only represent an increase in the scale of crop screening but also reveal genetic targets for plant breeding that have previously been obscured by genetic redundancy. With the ability to screen millions of cells, libraries can also be transfected at titers that lead to multiple guides per cell, effectively allowing higher order mutants to be screened quickly and easily. Many important stress tolerance traits are known to be mediated at the cell level, and marker assisted selection allows screening for targeted pathways that regulate tissue level traits. The project will assess the efficiency of CRISPR in maize cells in pilot experiments that target the auxin signaling pathway using auxin response markers as a selection tool.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the project was to develop new strategies for screening valuable agronomic traits in maize that take advantage of new plant “miniaturization” technologies. One new technology is CRISPR directed gene edited, which essentially allows researchers in virtually any organism to pick a gene for perturbation (or potential functional modifications). This can be done on the whole organism or on cells derived from an organism, the latter for which testing in mixtures of thousands or millions of cells. The use of cells is essentially a miniaturization of the screening process that allows for much higher throughput. The second technology is single-cell RNA-seq in which researchers can assay the activity of genes – through mRNA sequencing – in single cells. This essentially allows the miniaturization of phenotypic screening, permitting researchers to read out the phenotype of tens of thousands of cells at once. So, the two techniques are complementary, the first creating genetic variation in single cells and the second providing a way to examine the effects of those perturbations.

The goal of the project was to combine these two techniques – perturbation of cells via CRISPR technology and screening of those perturbed cells via single-cell RNA-seq. The project overcame the first challenge of efficiently introducing the CRISPR perturbation constructs into maize cells (transformation) by adjusting incubation conditions. This turned out to be a critical step because low transformation rates meant that the phenotypic screening would largely take place in cells that never received a construct for perturbation. That problem threatened to compromise the high-throughput nature of the assay and waste the vast majority of effort and expense on the sequencing side, the most costly party of the effort.

The project also adapted single-cell RNA-seq droplet-based approaches to maize root cells, generating three separate runs totaling about 5,000 cells. These cells were then identified to their tissue of origin, generating the first cell-by-cell map of the maize root transcriptome. The computer scientist on the project, Dr. Shasha, and his graduate student developed methods that analyze gene networks within cell types along the developmental trajectory defined by single-cell RNA-seq profiles.

The maize single-cell root transcriptome is data is being prepared now for inclusion in a manuscript that will be submitted shortly. The computational techniques developed by Dr. Shasha will appear in a separate manuscript. The COVID crisis hit the final months of the project in which we were planning to combine the CRISPR and RNA-seq techniques. One issue that remained was survival of cells that received the CRISPR-CAS9 construct, but this may have been due to problems with the vector unrelated to the CAS9 or guide RNAs. We plan to address this final issue following up through other NSF-funded projects as soon as the personnel responsible for the work can return to the lab.

In broader impacts, the PI was involved in plant community organization around the themes related to the grant. Dr. Birnbaum organized the FASEB Mechanisms In Plant Development meeting in summer of 2019, which included a Single-cell RNA-seq Workshop. The PI was also among a group of core organizers of the Plant Cell Atlas Workshop in 2020. The workshop moved from what was scheduled to be a small in-person meeting to a much larger format online, attracting hundreds of plant researchers from around the world. The PI is also organizing a fourth session of the workshop specifically on Single Cell RNA-seq.
